channel.title: Photos - Digg
channel.description: Photos on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: The Photographer Who Took The Viral Photos Of People In Scrubs Blocking Anti-Lockdown Protesters In Denver Described What Happened
item.description: Alyson McClaran said one of the anti-lockdown protesters pushed his car against a man in scrubs who was peacefully blocking protesters in Denver.

item.title: The Real Story Behind That Viral Photo Of President Johnson During The Vietnam War
item.description: It's an iconic image, but the photo is being taken out of context.

item.title: Is Isolation Overrepresented In Street And Documentary Photography?
item.description: Isolating individuals in photographs can make for an interesting image, but an entire portfolio of these images contains a statement, whether intentional or otherwise.

item.title: Colorado: Images of the Centennial State
item.description: A few glimpses of Colorado's landscape and some of the animals and people calling it home.
item.kicker: HIGH PLAINS TO THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS

item.title: Spain's Strangest Hotspots, And More Best Photography Of The Week
item.description: Living inside Brazil's largest apartment complex amid a pandemic, prophetic images of an empty world and other best photos of the week.

item.title: Cool Photos Show Lifestyle Of American Teens In The Late 1980s
item.description: The 1980s is the period of multi-style fashion, especially for young people in the United States.

item.title: The Epicenter: A Week Inside New York's Public Hospitals, In Photos
item.description: Inside the underfunded, overwhelmed public hospitals that are trying to save New York.

item.title: A Gallery Of Stunning Photos Of Classic Range Rover Conversions
item.description: The Range Rover has been a notable part of motoring since the beginning of the 1970s.

item.title: The Eerie Silence Of The Las Vegas Strip, In Photos
item.description: The empty strip, shut down for the first time since the JFK assassination, shows the striking toll the coronavirus crisis has taken on fun and leisure.

item.title: Every Day Since 1964, This Outsider Artist Made A Collage Of Found Objects
item.description: New Yorkers have a special relationship with trash, which is as much a fixture of the cityscape as the Manhattan skyline. Not to wax romantic about littering, but some of that, shall we say, "street ephemera" — the lost tickets, photos, business cards — can give us the most honest, intimate window into the city's stories.

item.title: Behold 'Dune': An Exclusive Look At Photos Of Denis Villeneuve's Sci-Fi Epic
item.description: Feuding royals. A deadly planet. Before "Star Wars" or "Game of Thrones," there was Frank Herbert's legendary sci-fi novel.

item.title: 12 Photos Of Animals Taking Over Towns And Cities On Lockdown
item.description: These photos of wildlife taking over the streets of towns and cities around the world will make you smile — from goats in Llandudno to ducks in Paris.

item.title: Easter Services In A Distanced World
item.description: Images from around the world showing what Easter Sunday services look like during a global pandemic.
item.kicker: PROBABLY SHOULDN'T HAVE RISEN QUITE YET

item.title: Apollo 13's Astronauts Survived Disaster 50 Years Ago. Could It Happen Again?
item.description: A trip to the moon later this decade should be safer, but it won't be safe.

item.title: Newly-Enhanced Images Of Life On Apollo 13
item.description: Unsurprisingly, given they were locked in a fight for survival, relatively few onboard images were taken. But imaging specialist Andy Saunders created sharp stills from low-quality 16mm film shot by the crew.

item.title: Airport Aerials: The Incredible Photo Project Looking Down On Airports
item.description: One of photographer Toby Harriman's personal projects over the past few years has been exploring the unique designs of different airports, and his slowly expanding Airport Aerials project is offering truly unique perspectives on these massive spaces.

item.title: Coronavirus Closure Returns Yosemite To The Animals
item.description: The deer, bobcats, coyotes and bears no longer have to deal with the hordes of camera-toting tourist vying to capture nature. They now roam unfettered.
item.kicker: WE ARE THE — ACTUALLY, THE VIRUS IS THE VIRUS

item.title: A Wedding On 3 Hours' Notice In A City Park
item.description: Emma and Jim's Fort Tryon Park wedding involved five guests, paper flowers made from a copy of Jane Austen's "Emma," and applause from fellow New Yorkers.

item.title: A Secret Family History, Reconstructed In The Present, And More Best Photography Of The Week
item.description: The absurdity and humor of Siberia, the genius architecture of the Red Wall and more best photos of the week.

item.title: A Year-Long Expedition Spotlights Night Life In The Arctic Winter
item.description: In a ship deliberately embedded in an ice floe, scientists are studying the base of the food web.

item.title: The Creative And Sometimes Cramped Ways People Live Together
item.description: The different ways people share the cost of rent — and in the process, their chores, childcare and lives.

item.title: This Is What The Future Of Human Evolution Looks Like
item.description: "Science and human advancement has always been propelled forward by the people who do things differently and those who are not afraid to break the rules."

item.title: This Pilot Took Rare Aerial Photos Of Area 51
item.description: Private pilot Gabriel Zeifman took to the skies this past weekend and captured some rare aerial photos of Area 51.

item.title: A Photographer Captured Breathtaking Images Of A 'Horizontal Rainbow' Over A Lake In Washington
item.description: Amateur photographer Cessna Kutz took two photos of the "horizontal rainbow" from her porch located on Lake Sammamish in Washington.

item.title: Hong Kong At Night In The 1960s Through Amazing Color Photos
item.description: 1960s in Hong Kong continued with the development and expansion of manufacturing that began in the previous decade.These color photos were found by Martin Snelling.

item.title: See Every Square Foot Of Asteroid Bennu, Earth's Little Frenemy
item.description: Bennu has the distinction of being the subject of the highest resolution mosaic ever made of any planetary body.

item.title: Inside The World's Largest Particle Collider
item.description: The Large Hadron Collider (LHC), operated by the European Council for Nuclear Research (CERN), is a 27 km ring buried 100 meters underground between France and Switzerland.
item.kicker: LIGHT AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL

item.title: The People Staying And Living In America's Motels, And More Best Photography Of The Week
item.description: The inside world of Irish traveler children, a testosterone-fueled pool hall in Chicago and more best photos of the week.

item.title: The World's Great Photographers, Many Stuck Inside, Have Snapped
item.description: Stephen Shore, Catherine Opie, Todd Hido and others have turned to Instagram to cure "corona claustrophobia" or show how life has changed. They talk about their quarantine pics.

item.title: Italy's Lockdown, Photographed Through A Rear Window
item.description: Filippo Venturi documents a neighborhood making the most of its yard time.
item.kicker: LIVE IN THE PLACE WHERE YOU WERE

item.title: A Peek At Utopian Space Dreams Behind The Iron Curtain
item.description: A new collection of Soviet space design is more relevant than ever.
item.kicker: 'WITHOUT YOUR PAST, YOU CANNOT MOVE ON'

item.title: This App That Turns Your Photos In Paintings In The Style Of Famous Artists Is A Perfect Way To Waste Some Time
item.description: Even seemingly ordinary photos can look extraordinary when you transform it in the style of a Van Gogh or an Andy Warhol.

item.title: How To Take And Send Nudes
item.description: There's never been a better time to master the fine art of the naked selfie.

item.title: A Visual History Of Chinese Propaganda
item.description: Striking posters — taken from the 1920s to the present day — chart the country's emergence as an economic powerhouse.

item.title: The Complicated New World Of Voyeurism
item.description: The nature of the worldwide lockdowns has us all looking out of our windows significantly more, searching for something or someone to uplift, inform or entertain us.

item.title: The Doctor Holding The Camera
item.description: Patrick Schnell is a photographer — and a pediatrician who worked in hospitals for 14 years. He has photographed inside Mt. Sinai Brooklyn on numerous occasions before, but says he has never seen anything like this.
item.kicker: 'I JUST WANT TO SHOW WHAT'S GOING ON'

item.title: Ozark Life: A Photo Essay Of The Intimate Beauty Of Daily Life In Rural Arkansas
item.description: Motor down just one dirt road, and you'll begin to collect moments that are unique to this part of the South we call the Ozark Hills.

item.title: Vintage Holiday Photographs Placed In Their Original Settings
item.description: There's an old untruth that says other people's holiday snaps are boring. It's the kind of thing said by people with no taste who want to pretend they have taste. A slightly superior taste to you or me.

item.title: Un-baaaaa-lievable: Goats Invade Locked-Down Welsh Town
item.description: The goats normally keep largely to themselves, in a country park that butts up against Llandudno. But now emboldened by the lack of people and cars, the long-horned animals are venturing deeper into the seaside town.
item.kicker: WHERE THE STREETS HAVE GOAT NAMES

item.title: Wuhan Begins To Lift Its Coronavirus Lockdown
item.description: Wuhan, where the coronavirus outbreak first emerged, began lifting a two-month lockdown on Saturday by restarting some metro services and reopening borders, allowing some semblance of normality to return and families to reunite.

item.title: A Moment For Drive-In Movie Theaters, In Photos
item.description: Moviegoers attending drive-ins during the pandemic — finding entertainment outside their homes, together with others, yet safely apart.
item.kicker: SIX FEET AND TWO CAR DOORS APART

item.title: What Happens When Two Strangers Trust The Rides Of Their Lives To The Magic Of The Universe
item.description: Leon had been riding west for 309 days. Noel had headed east for 176. Their meeting in the desert was a small miracle.

item.title: Photographs Of The Longest Running Unsolved Treasure Hunt In The World
item.description: Over 25 years ago, golden treasure was buried somewhere in the landscape of France, and it is yet to be found. But Emily's series is about much more than a trail gone cold.

item.title: A Secret Family History, Reconstructed In The Present
item.description: Diana Markosian left her childhood home in the former Soviet Union for a new life in California. But it was a journey she never chose to take. To understand her mother's choices, she had to recreate the first chapter of a story that would inspire her most ambitious project yet.

item.title: New York Was Not Designed For Emptiness
item.description: The energy, the traffic, the crowds are all gone. Only the vacant streets remain, waiting for the actors to return to the stage.

item.title: North Dakota: Images Of The Peace Garden State
item.description: A few glimpses of North Dakota's landscape and some of the animals and people calling it home.

item.title: 'We Take The Dead From Morning Till Night'
item.description: The streets of Bergamo are empty. As in all of Italy, people can leave their homes only for food and medicines and work. The factories and shops and schools are closed. There is no more chatting on the corners or in the coffee bars.

item.title: Life In Earth's Deepest Deep Freeze, And More Best Photography Of The Week
item.description: The weird and wonderful world of British car boot sales, a journey to Japan's centuries-old festivals and more best photos of the week.

item.title: The Colorful Photographs Of Everyday Life That Shocked The Art World And Changed Photography Forever
item.description: Self-taught photographer William Eggleston's vivid images of mundane scenes arrived at MoMA at a time when the only photographs considered to be art were in black and white.

item.title: Here's How The World Is Sanitizing Streets
item.description: Around the world, nations are enacting unprecedented sanitation measures to help combat the spread of the coronavirus.
